Uffizi, da cui il Palazzo prenderÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â  il nome, ubicate allora in sedi separate. Fu Francesco I poi , a realizzarci allÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢interno una vera e propria Galleria

La Galleria degli Uffizi ÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¨ collegata a Palazzo Pitti, attraverso un passaggio sopraelevato, che si origina al secondo corridoio della Galleria e che si 

estende poi lungo lÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢Arno, sopra il Ponte Vecchio, fino a raggiungere la residenza della famiglia Medici dallÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢altra parte del fiume, Palazzo Pitti appunto.
Il Corridoio fu realizzato in soli 5 mesi per volere del Granduca Cosimo I, con lo scopo di agevolare il passaggio tra gli Uffici dei Medici allÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢interno 

della Galleria degli Uffizi e lÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢allora residenza (Palazzo Pitti). Il mercato delle carni che si svolgeva su Ponte Vecchio fu trasferito per evitare cattivi 

odori al passaggio del granduca e al suo posto furono spostate le botteghe degli orafi che ancora oggi occupano il ponte.
Questa struttura, lunga un chilometro, ospita oggi sia una parte della collezione di dipinti del Seicento e del Settecento degli Uffizi che quella degli

della Chiesa stessa cosÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¬ come lo vedevano i Medici quando assistevano alle funzioni; lungo una parete cÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¨ infatti una finestra che si affaccia su quello che

[color=RED][B]Tour Uffizi Gallery and Vasarian Corridor[/b][/color]
[color=BLACK]

The Uffizi Gallery is the second museum in Italy for visitors number, hosting a wonderful masterpieces collection coming from a rich past of creativity and 

artistic fantasy, that includes also the main BotticelliÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s paintings collection, divided in different halls according to styles and schools, in a 

chronological order.
Wanted by Cosimo I, around the first half of XVI cent., the Gallery was planned by the architect Giorgio Vasari, in order to host the thirteen ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œofficesÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ or 

ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œUffiziÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ from which the building will take the name, before located in different seats. Francesco I then , decided to carry out there a real Art Gallery to 

delight his passage inside the building.

The Uffizi Gallery is connected to Pitti Palace through a raised passage, originating in the GalleryÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s second corridor and extending along the river to reach 

the Medici familiyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s residence, on the other side of the river, just Pitti Palace.
The Corridor was realized in only 5 months for the Granduke Cosimo IÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s will, in order to facilitate the passage between the MediciÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s Offices, inside the 

Uffizi Gallery and the then residence (Pitti Palace). The meat market taking place on the Old bridge was removed to avoid bad smells during the GrandukeÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s 

passage and it was replaced by some gold shops that still today occupy the bridge.
The raised passage, one kilometre long, hosts today a part of the UffiziÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s paintings collection and the biggest portraits selection in the world and it 

probably represents the most suggestive place for the visitor, evocating fantasies If under an architectural point of view, the idea of a raised passage was 

very innovative, the interior, besides the mentioned collections, distinguish itself overall by a scenographical view on the river and on the Santa Felicita 

Church.
In reality, from the corridor it is possible to see the interior of the church as so the Medici family saw it when they assisted the Mass, without being seen 

by the people staying at the ground floor ; along a wall there is indeed a window facing the original Medicean stage.[/b][/color]
